{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Motorsport season |series = NASCAR Sprint Cup Series |link = NASCAR Sprint Cup Series |year = 2011 }} {{portal|NASCAR}} [[File:TonyStewartAugust2007.jpg|thumb|right|[[Tony Stewart]], the 2011 Cup Champion]] [[File:Carl Edwards, 2011 (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|[[Carl Edwards]] came in second behind Stewart by a tie breaker]] [[File:Kevin Harvick at Zanesville Ohio 2006.jpg|thumb|right|[[Kevin Harvick]] finished third in the championship]] The '''2011 NASCAR Sprint Cup Series season''' was the 63rd season of [[Sprint Cup Series|professional]] [[stock car racing]] in the United States. The season included 36 races and two exhibition races, beginning with the [[2011 Daytona 500|Daytona 500]] at [[Daytona International Speedway]] and ending with the [[2011 Ford 400|Ford 400]] at [[Homestead-Miami Speedway]]. The final ten races were known as [[2011 Chase for the Sprint Cup]]. During the [[2010 NASCAR Sprint Cup Series|2010 season]], NASCAR announced several calendar changes, including race additions at [[Kansas Speedway]] and [[Kentucky Speedway]], and the removal of one race each from [[Atlanta Motor Speedway]] and [[Auto Club Speedway]]. Once the 2010 season had concluded, NASCAR also announced changes to the point system, and that the fuel changed from [[Sunoco]] [[gasoline|unleaded]] to an [[Ethanol fuel|ethanol]] blend called 'Sunoco Green [[E15 fuel|E15]]'. Margaret Haas won the Owners' Championship, while [[Tony Stewart]] co-owner of [[Stewart Haas Racing]] with [[Gene Haas]], won the Drivers' Championship with a victory at the [[Ford 400|final race of the season]]. [[Chevrolet]] won the Manufacturers' Championship with 248 points.
==Preseason== [[File:The NASCAR nose for 2011.jpg|200px|left|thumb|The new front end (shown here prior to the [[2011 Daytona 500]] at [[Daytona International Speedway]]) that was being used during the season.]] The preseason testing season began on January 20, 2011 with a three-day test at the [[Daytona International Speedway]] to test the new nose on the car, as well as the new surface. Also in the sessions, the opening of the [[restrictor plate]] was reduced from the 30 / 32 inch plate used in tire testing in December to 29 /32 inch. NASCAR vice president for competition [[Robin Pemberton]] stated, "We'll have to get back and talk to the teams and look at the speeds from the last two days of testing. I think we have some high-water marks at 197-and-a-half which, depending on where they pulled up in the draft, it may be a little quick, but it's hard to say."<ref>{{cite web|author=Dave Rodman, NASCAR.COM |url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110113/restrictor-plate-size-thunder/index.html |title=NASCAR reducing restrictor plate for Daytona test â Jan 13, 2011 |publisher=Nascar.Com |accessdate=January 13, 2011}}</ref> <ref name='testing1202011' >{{cite news|title=Preseason Thunder dates set for Jan. 20â22|url=http://www.nascar.com/2010/news/headlines/official/10/09/daytona-preseason-thunder-2011/index.html|accessdate=October 9, 2010|newspaper=NASCAR|date=October 9, 2010|author=Official Release}}</ref> During the first session on the morning of January 20, 2011, 33 drivers participated, and [[Clint Bowyer]] was quickest with a speed of 184.216 mph<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nascar.speedtv.com/article/cup-clint-bowyer-has-fastest-daytona-nascar-test-session-speed/ |title=NASCAR â CUP: Bowyer Has Fastest Test-Session Speed |publisher=Nascar.speedtv.com |accessdate=January 21, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scenedaily.com/news/articles/sprintcupseries/Speeds_down_track_extremely_smooth_as_Clint_Bowyer_leads_first_test_session_at_Daytona.html |title=Speeds down, track extremely smooth as Clint Bowyer leads first test session at Daytona | NASCAR News Now |publisher=SceneDaily.com |accessdate=January 21, 2011}}</ref> while [[David Reutimann]] had the highest speed of 195.780 mph during the second session in the afternoon.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.catchfence.com/2011/sprintcup/01/20/2011-nscs-nascar-preseason-thunder-day-1-afternoon-drafting-session-speeds/ |title=2011 NSCS NASCAR Preseason Thunder Day 1 â Afternoon Drafting Session Speeds |publisher=Catchfence |accessdate=January 21, 2011}}</ref>
The third test session, scheduled for the morning of January 21, was canceled because of wet weather. During the fourth session, held during the afternoon, 34 drivers participated with [[Denny Hamlin]] being quickest with a speed of 196.868 mph.<ref name='testing20110121' >{{cite news|url=http://www.scenedaily.com/news/articles/sprintcupseries/Teams_work_on_two-car_draft_at_Daytona_during_second_day_of_testing.html |title=Teams work on two-car draft at Daytona during second day of testing | NASCAR News Now |publisher=SceneDaily.com |accessdate=January 22, 2011}}</ref> Several drivers decided to leave after the session, which included Reutimann, [[Martin Truex, Jr.]], [[Jimmie Johnson]], and Bowyer.<ref name=testing20110121 /> During the fifth session, held on the morning of January 22, 29 drivers participated, and [[Joey Logano]] was quickest with a speed of 197.516 mph.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nascar.speedtv.com/article/cup-joey-logano-denny-hamlin-cross-197-barrier-at-daytona/ |title=NASCAR â CUP: Logano, Hamlin Cross 197 Barrier At Daytona |publisher=Nascar.speedtv.com |accessdate=January 22, 2011}}</ref> [[Brad Keselowski]] was quickest with a speed of 198.605 mph in the final session.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110122/preseason-thunder-day-3-release/index.html |title=Two-car drafts dominate final day of Thunder â Jan 22, 2011 |publisher=Nascar.Com |date=January 22, 2011 |accessdate=January 23, 2011}}</ref> Once the testing concluded, NASCAR managing director of competition John Darby commented that he did not expect to change the restrictor plate that they used in the January test sessions, leaving the opening at 29 /32 inches.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dave Rodman, NASCAR.COM |url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110123/preseason-thunder-speeds-not-concerning/index.html |title=Officials not worried about speeds at Thunder â Jan 23, 2011 |publisher=Nascar.Com |accessdate=January 24, 2011}}</ref>
==Report== [[File:Carl Edwards celebrating his 2011 Las Vegas Victory.jpg|thumb|250px|left|[[Carl Edwards]], before performing his signature [[backflip]] after winning the [[2011 Kobalt Tools 400|Kobalt Tools 400]], his only victory of the season]] In the first exhibition race of the season, the [[2011 Budweiser Shootout]], Hamlin crossed the finished line in the first position, but since he passed below the yellow out of bounds line, [[Kurt Busch]] became the winner of the race.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sporting News Wire Service |url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110212/kbusch-wins-shootout/index.html |title=Busch wins Shootout as Hamlin black-flagged â Feb 13, 2011 |publisher=Nascar.Com |date=February 13, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref> [[Trevor Bayne]] won the opening race of the season in the [[2011 Daytona 500|Daytona 500]] after [[David Ragan]] received a penalty for a restart violation, with Bayne becoming just the fifth driver to win the race for [[Wood Brothers Racing]] and the youngest ever to win the Daytona 500 at 20 years and 1 day.<ref name=53Daytona500 /> Four-time champion, [[Jeff Gordon]] claimed victory in the [[2011 Subway Fresh Fit 500]] at [[Phoenix International Raceway]], after leading the most laps of 138, ending a 66-race winless streak.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/nascar/cup/news/story?id=6165367 |title=Jeff Gordon wins at Phoenix to snap 66-race drought â ESPN |publisher=ESPN |date=February 28, 2011 |accessdate=July 10, 2011}}</ref>
Next, [[Carl Edwards]] won the [[2011 Kobalt Tools 400]] after [[Tony Stewart]], who led the most laps, was penalized on pit road.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.garnernews.net/view/full_story/12233261/article-Edwards%E2%80%99s-pit-strategy--Stewart-s-pit-error-equal-win-at-Vegas?instance=secondary_sports_left_column |title=Edwardsâs pit strategy, Stewart's pit error equal win at Vegas Read more: Garner News â Edwardsâs pit strategy Stewart s pit error equal win at Vegas |publisher=Garnernews.net |accessdate=July 10, 2011}}</ref> After winning the [[Scotts EZ Seed 300|Nationwide race]] on Saturday, [[Kyle Busch]] held off [[Carl Edwards]] and [[Jimmie Johnson]] to take his fifth consecutive Bristol victory.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sporting News Wire Service |url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110320/kybusch-wins-bristol-cup/index.html |title=Busch's Bristol roll continues with Cup victory â Mar 21, 2011 |publisher=Nascar.Com |date=March 21, 2011 |accessdate=July 10, 2011}}</ref> Though Kyle dominated the race, [[Jimmie Johnson]] took the lead briefly but was passed on the last lap by [[Kevin Harvick]], who took his first win of 2011 at [[Auto Club Speedway]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.motorracingnetwork.com/Race-Series/NASCAR-Sprint-Cup/News/Articles/2011/03/Thrilling-Home-Win-for-Harvick.aspx |title=Thrilling Home Win for Kevin Harvick |publisher=MotorRacingNetwork.com |date=March 27, 2011 |accessdate=July 10, 2011}}</ref> The following week, Harvick passed fan favorite [[Dale Earnhardt, Jr.]] with four laps to go to win at [[Martinsville Speedway]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Sporting News Wire Service |url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110403/kharvick-win-martinsville/index.html |title=Harvick edges past Earnhardt for Martinsville win â Apr 4, 2011 |publisher=Nascar.Com |accessdate=July 10, 2011}}</ref> [[Roush Fenway Racing]] dominated the weekend at [[Texas Motor Speedway]], with [[Matt Kenseth]] leading 169 laps en route to his first victory in 76 races.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sporting News Wire Service |url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110409/mkenseth-wins-cup-texas/index.html |title=Kenseth snaps long drought in easy Texas victory â Apr 11, 2011 |publisher=Nascar.Com |date=April 11, 2011 |accessdate=July 10, 2011}}</ref> [[File:Kyle Busch, 2011 Goody's Fast Relief 500.jpg|200px|right|thumb|[[Kyle Busch]] (car shown above) is tied with [[Kevin Harvick]] for the second most wins during the season with four]] In the [[2011 Aaron's 499|Aaron's 499]] that tied the Sprint Cup Series record for the most lead changes in a race, [[Jimmie Johnson]] edged [[Clint Bowyer]] for the win at [[Talladega Superspeedway]] by .002 seconds, tying the closest finish in series history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/nascar/cup/news/story?id=6376741 |title=Jimmie Johnson takes Talladega in tie for closest Sprint Cup victory â ESPN |publisher=ESPN |date=April 18, 2011 |accessdate=July 10, 2011}}</ref> For the third consecutive season, [[Kyle Busch]] dominated the spring race at [[Richmond International Raceway|Richmond]], leading 293 of 400 laps en route to his second win of the season<ref>{{cite web|author=Sporting News Wire Service |url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110430/kybusch-wins-richmond/index.html |title=Busch springs to another victory at Richmond â May 2, 2011 |publisher=Nascar.Com |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=July 10, 2011}}</ref> After being denied victory at Talladega in 2008, [[Regan Smith]] stayed out on older tires and held of points leader [[Carl Edwards]] for his and [[Furniture Row Racing]]'s first Cup Series victory at [[Darlington Raceway]].<ref>{{cite web|author=  |url=http://charlotte.news14.com/content/top_stories/640656/regan-smith-survives-at-darlington-raceway |title=Regan Smith survives at Darlington Raceway |publisher=Charlotte.news14.com |accessdate=July 10, 2011}}</ref> Making a last minute two-tire pit stop on the final pit stop, [[Matt Kenseth]] outran former teammate [[Mark Martin]] to take his second win of the season at [[Dover International Speedway|Dover]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Sporting News Wire Service |url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110515/mkenseth-dover-win/index.html |title=Latecomer Kenseth steals a victory at Dover |publisher=Nascar.com |date=May 16, 2011 |accessdate=July 10, 2011}}</ref>
At the second exhibition race of the season, the [[NASCAR Sprint All-Star Race XXVII]] at [[Charlotte Motor Speedway]], [[David Ragan]] and [[Brad Keselowski]] finished 1â2 in the Sprint Showdown, while fan favorite [[Dale Earnhardt, Jr.]] won the fan vote to transfer into the main event.<ref name="sprintshowdown">{{cite news | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/nascar/2011-05-21-David-Ragan-wins-Sprint-Showdown_N.htm | title=Ragan, Keselowski, Earnhardt Jr. advance to all-star race | date=May 21, 2011 | agency=USA Today | accessdate=July 28, 2011 | author=Ryan, Nate | location=Concord, North Carolina}}</ref> [[Carl Edwards]] dominated the final two segments and held off [[Kyle Busch]] for his first All-Star victory.<ref name="edwardsallstar">{{cite news | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/nascar/2011-05-21-Carl-Edwards-wins-NASCAR-Sprint-All-Star-Race_N.htm | title=Carl Edwards breezes to first victory in Sprint All-Star Race | date=May 21, 2011 | agency=USA Today | accessdate=July 28, 2011 | author=Ryan, Nate | location=Concord, North Carolina}}</ref> With the teams remaining in Charlotte for the [[Coca-Cola 600]], [[Dale Earnhardt, Jr.]] came close to snapping his winless drought by gambling on fuel, but ran out of gas on the backstretch, allowing [[Kevin Harvick]] to drive to his 3rd win of 2011.<ref name="kevinwins600">{{cite web | url=http://nascar.speedtv.com/article/cup-harvick-wins-at-cms/ | title=NASCAR â CUP: Harvick Wins Charlotte In Bizarre Finish | publisher=Speedtv.com | date=May 29, 2011 | accessdate=July 28, 2011 | author=Hembree, Mike}}</ref> At 402 laps and 603 miles, the race was the longest in NASCAR history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://racingnewsdigest.com/2011/05/kevin-harvick-wins-coke-cola-600-longest-nascar-race-ever-crazy-finish/|work=Racing News Digest|date=2011-05-29|publisher=Racing News Digest|accessdate=2011-10-30|title=Kevin Harvick Wins Coke Cola 600 â Longest NASCAR Race Ever â Crazy Finish}}</ref> At the inaugural [[STP 400]] at [[Kansas Speedway]], a dominant [[Kurt Busch]] was forced to stop for fuel with 7 laps to go, allowing teammate [[Brad Keselowski]] to take the lead and hold off a charging Dale Earnhardt, Jr. for his second Sprint Cup victory.<ref name="keselowskikansasfirst">{{cite web | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/nascar/cup/news/story?id=6628733 | title=Brad Keselowski wins at Kansas | publisher=ESPN | date=June 6, 2011 | accessdate=July 28, 2011 | author=Associated Press}}</ref> At the [[5-hour Energy 500]], a quick final pit stop enabled [[Jeff Gordon]] to beat polesitter [[Kurt Busch]] out of the pits, getting Gordon his 84th Sprint Cup victory, tying [[Bobby Allison]] and [[Darrell Waltrip]] for third on the all-time wins list and also tying Waltrip for the most wins in NASCAR's modern era.<ref name="gordonwinsfirstpocono">{{cite web | url=http://nascar.speedtv.com/article/cup-jeff-gordon-wins-at-pocono/ | title=UP: Jeff Gordon Smokes Field At Pocono | publisher=Speedtv.com | date=June 12, 2011 | accessdate=July 28, 2011 | author=Hembree, Mike}}</ref> The next week at [[Michigan International Speedway|Michigan]], defending race winner [[Denny Hamlin]] got an excellent final pit stop, enabling him to hold off [[Matt Kenseth]] for his first win of the season.<ref name="hamlinwinsfirstmichigan">{{cite web | url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110619/dhamlin-wins-michigan/index.html | title=Hamlin holds off Kenseth for win at Michigan | publisher=Nascar.com | date=June 20, 2011 | accessdate=July 28, 2011 | author=Sporting News Wire Service}}</ref> The next week at [[Infineon Raceway]], [[Kurt Busch]] dominated the race and easily held off [[Jeff Gordon]] for his first win of 2011 and first on a road course.<ref name="kurtbuschwinsinfineon">{{cite web | url=http://www.motorracingnetwork.com/Race-Series/NASCAR-Sprint-Cup/News/Articles/2011/06/Busch-Takes-Road-to-Victory.aspx | title=Busch Takes Road to Victory | publisher=Motorracingnetwork.com | date=June 26, 2011 | accessdate=July 28, 2011}}</ref>
The series returned to Daytona for the [[Independence Day]] weekend. Daytona 500 winner [[Trevor Bayne]] crashed out early, and [[David Ragan]] with help from teammate [[Matt Kenseth]], rebounded from his late 500 loss to take his first Sprint Cup victory.<ref name="usatodayraganwinsdaytona400">{{cite news | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/nascar/2011-07-02-sprint-cup-coke-zero-400_n.htm | title=David Ragan wins at Daytona for first Sprint Cup victory | date=July 2, 2011 | accessdate=July 28, 2011 | agency=USA Today | author=Ryan, Nate | location=Daytona Beach, Florida}}</ref> The following week, at the inaugural [[Quaker State 400]] at [[Kentucky Speedway]], [[Kyle Busch]] dominated the race and held off a hard charging [[David Reutimann]] for his third win of the season.<ref name="kylewinskentucky">{{cite news | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/nascar/2011-07-09-sprint-cup-kentucky_n.htm | title=Kyle Busch wins inaugural Sprint Cup race at Kentucky | date=July 9, 2011 | agency=USA Today | accessdate=July 28, 2011 | author=Ryan, Nate | location=Sparta, Kentucky}}</ref> Heading up to [[New England]] for the [[Lenox Industrial Tools 301]] at Loudon, [[Ryan Newman]] and [[Tony Stewart]], both drivers for [[Stewart Haas Racing]] started first and second on the grid, and the two remained in the same order at the conclusion of the race, Newman's his first win of season.<ref name="newmanwinsnewhampshire301">{{cite web | url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110717/rnewman-win-loudon/ | title=Newman, Stewart run 1â2 at New Hampshire | publisher=Nascar.com | date=July 18, 2011 | accessdate=July 28, 2011 | author=Sporting News Wire Service}}</ref> After an off week, the series made its way to the prestigious [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] for the [[Brickyard 400]]. Though [[Jeff Gordon]] had the dominant car, pit strategy got [[Paul Menard]] out front and eventually hold off a hard-charging Gordon for his first career Sprint Cup victory.
The series returned to Pocono for the [[Good Sam RV Insurance 500]]. The [[Joe Gibbs Racing]] trio of [[Denny Hamlin]], [[Kyle Busch]], and [[Joey Logano]] dominated the race, but [[Brad Keselowski]], racing injured from a crash at [[Road Atlanta]], held off Busch with 10 to go to take his second win of the year. The next week at [[Heluva Good! Sour Cream Dips at The Glen|Watkins Glen]], Cup drivers returned to road course racing, and [[Marcos Ambrose]] held off Brad Keselowski and Kyle Busch in a green-white-checker finish and avoided several violent crashes, including [[David Reutimann]] flipping in the esses on the final lap, to claim his first Sprint Cup Series win, becoming the fifth first-time winner in 2011. Ambrose also became the first [[Australia]]n ever (and fourth foreign-born driver) to win a Cup Series race.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-sport/marcos-ambrose-claims-maiden-nascar-win-20110816-1iv4v.html |title=Marcos Ambrose claims maiden NASCAR win |first=Rob |last=Forsaith |agency=[[Australian Associated Press]] |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=August 16, 2011 |accessdate=August 17, 2011}}</ref> The series returned to Michigan for the [[Pure Michigan 400]], and [[Kyle Busch]] would dominate the race and hold off [[Jimmie Johnson]] for his fourth win of 2011. Heading to Bristol for the [[Irwin Tools Night Race]], [[Jeff Gordon]] dominated the race, but [[Brad Keselowski]] got out front after a fast final pitstop and held off [[Martin Truex, Jr.]] for his third win of 2011.
Heading to [[Atlanta Motor Speedway]] for the [[Labor Day]] weekend, the race was pushed to Tuesday [[September 6]] due to [[Tropical Storm Lee (2011)|Tropical Storm Lee]] dumping rain on the Southwest Sunday and Monday. When the race resumed, [[Jeff Gordon]] held off [[Hendrick Motorsports]] teammate [[Jimmie Johnson]] for his 3rd win of 2011 and his 85th overall win in the Cup Series. At the [[Wonderful Pistachios 400]], the last race of the regular season was hotly contested with multiple drivers needing a win to break into the Chase. [[Kevin Harvick]] would end up holding off the field for his 4th win of 2011 while [[Denny Hamlin]] and [[Brad Keselowski]] completed the two wild card spots in the top 12. For the first time, [[Chicagoland Speedway]] was the site of the Chase opener. With the race delayed until Monday due to rain, [[Tony Stewart]] held off a hard-charging [[Kevin Harvick]] and outlasted the field on fuel to take his first win of 2011. The teams headed up north to return to [[New Hampshire Motor Speedway]] for the [[Sylvania 300]]. Once again, the race came down to fuel milage as [[Tony Stewart]] passed [[Clint Bowyer]] with 2 laps to go and held on for his second consecutive win of the year. In the series' return to Dover, [[Jimmie Johnson]] dominated the race, but [[Kurt Busch]] took advantage of a restart and held off Johnson for his second win of 2011. Heading to Kansas, Jimmie Johnson once again dominated the race, but sealed up his second win of the season on a [[Green-white-checkered]] finish by holding off [[Kasey Kahne]].
The series returned to Charlotte for the halfway mark of the Chase. [[Kyle Busch]] dominated the race, but [[Matt Kenseth]] passed Busch late in the race and held him off for his third win of 2011. At Talladega, the controversial two-car draft was the order of the day, as the [[Richard Childress Racing|RCR]] duo of [[Jeff Burton]] and [[Clint Bowyer]] pulled away from the field on a late restart, though Bowyer would pass Burton on the final lap and beat him to the line by a fender for his second consecutive fall Talladega win. The teams returned to Martinsville for the final short track of the season. There, the Chase drivers had up and down days, but [[Tony Stewart]] passed [[Jimmie Johnson]] on the final restart to grab his third win of 2011 and keep his Chase hopes alive. Returning to Texas, Stewart dominated and passed a gambling [[Jeff Burton]] with 5 to go to hold off points leader [[Carl Edwards]] for his fourth win in 2011. At the penultimate race in Phoenix, the drivers face a completely new [[Phoenix International Raceway]]. Stewart dominated once again, but [[Kasey Kahne]] held off a hard-charging [[Carl Edwards]] to snap a 81 race winless streak. At the [[Ford 400|season finale]], championship contenders Edwards and Stewart dominated the race with a razor-thin points gap, but Stewart prevailed and took home both his fifth win of 2011 and defeated Edwards in a tiebreak for his first Cup championship as an owner-driver.

===Team changes=== In preparation for 2011, [[Penske Racing]] made team changes by moving Brad Keselowski, along with his No. 12 team, into the No. 2 Miller Lite car, replacing [[Kurt Busch]] and his 2010 team, who moved to the newly formed No. 22 Shell/Pennzoil car.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bradracing.com/brad-keselowski-to-pilot-blue-deuce-starting-in-2011/ |title=Brad Keselowski To Pilot Blue Deuce Starting In 2011 | Brad Keselowski Racing |publisher=Bradracing.com |date=April 1, 2010 |accessdate=January 24, 2011}}</ref> Another change was made by [[Hendrick Motorsports]], who rearranged three of the four car team. The team moved [[Steve Letarte]] with [[Dale Earnhardt, Jr.]], [[Alan Gustafson]] with [[Jeff Gordon]], and [[Lance McGrew]] with [[Mark Martin]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/nascar/2010-11-23-hendrick-motorsports-crew-chiefs_N.htm |title=Hendrick Motorsports shuffles crew chiefs for three teams |work=USA Today |date=November 24, 2010 |accessdate=January 24, 2011}}</ref> On January 7, 2011, Bob Leavine and Lance Fenton announced the formation of Leavine Fenton Racing, and that [[David Starr]] drove for the team.<ref>{{cite web|author=Team Release |url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110107/leavine-fenton-racing-formed/index.html?eref=/news/headlines/cup |title=Texans partner to form new race team â Jan 7, 2011 |publisher=Nascar.Com |date=January 7, 2011 |accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> In February, another team was formed, FAS Lane Racing, by [[Frank Stoddard]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.motorsport.com/news/article.asp?ID=399154 |title=News > Frank Stoddard forms new team |publisher=Motorsport.com |date=January 19, 2011 |accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> In March, [[David Stremme]] announced his return to the Cup Series with a new team, Inception Motorsports. They ran the No.30 Chevrolet and attempted to make the [[Crown Royal Presents the Your Name Here 400|Crown Royal Presents the Matthew and Daniel Hansen 400]] at Richmond.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inceptionmotorsports.com/news/2011/03-30-David-Stremme-Returning-to-NASCAR-Sprint-Cup-Series.html |title=David Stremme Returning to NASCAR Sprint Cup Series |publisher=Inception Motorsports |date=April 30, 2011 |accessdate=July 10, 2011}}</ref>In October before the [[Bank of America 500]], it was announced that [[Sinica Motorsports]] would join the Cup Series for 3 races in 2011, running the #93 Chevrolet with either [[Bill Elliott]] or [[Terry Labonte]] and that ARCA driver [[Grant Enfinger]] would drive for the team for 10-15 races in 2012.
===Driver changes=== ====Changed teams==== Several drivers changed teams for the season. One of which was Paul Menard, who left [[Richard Petty Motorsports]] to drive for [[Richard Childress Racing]].<ref name="menard">{{cite news|last=Release|first=Team|title=RCR signs Menard, returns to four-car stable|url=http://www.nascar.com/2010/news/headlines/cup/08/11/pmenard.rcr.fourth.car/index.html|accessdate=August 23, 2010|newspaper=NASCAR|date=August 11, 2010}}</ref> Menard signed a three year deal to expire at the end of 2013, with options for further years. Other changes were [[Kasey Kahne]] who joined the [[Red Bull Racing Team]], after leaving Richard Petty Motorsports in 2010,<ref name="kaseykahne">{{cite news|last=Release|first=Team|title=Kahne to drive for Red Bull Racing Team in 2011|url=http://www.nascar.com/2010/news/headlines/cup/08/09/kkahne.red.bull.2011/index.html|accessdate=October 16, 2010|newspaper=NASCAR|date=August 10, 2010}}</ref> and [[Marcos Ambrose]] who left [[JTG Daugherty Racing]] to drive for Richard Petty Motorsports in 2011, as a replacement for Kahne.<ref name="kahne">{{cite news|last=Release|first=Team|title=Ambrose signs with Richard Petty Motorsports |url=http://www.nascar.com/2010/news/headlines/cup/08/17/mambrose.signs.richard.petty.motorsports/index.html|accessdate=October 16, 2010|newspaper=NASCAR|date=August 17, 2010}}</ref> Also, [[Bobby Labonte]] replaced Ambrose at JTG Daugherty Racing,<ref name="labonte">{{cite news|last=Release|first=Team|title=Labonte to drive for JTG Daugherty in 2011|url=http://www.nascar.com/2010/news/headlines/cup/07/28/blabonte.jtg.daugherty.racing/index.html|newspaper=NASCAR|accessdate=October 17, 2010|date=July 28, 2010}}</ref> and [[Bill Elliott]], who moved from [[Wood Brothers Racing]] to [[Phoenix Racing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nascar/story/Bill-Elliott-to-drive-for-Phoenix-Racing-in-NASCAR-Sprint-Cup-Series-011710 |title=Lee Spencer: Bill Elliott to drive for Phoenix Racing in NASCAR Sprint Cup Series â NASCAR News | FOX Sports on MSN |publisher=Msn.foxsports.com |date=January 17, 2011 |accessdate=January 21, 2011}}</ref> [[Kevin Conway (NASCAR)|Kevin Conway]], the 2010 [[NASCAR Rookie of the Year]] in the Sprint Cup Series, also made a change by moving to [[NEMCO Motorsports]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scenedaily.com/news/articles/sprintcupseries/Kevin_Conway_to_drive_for_Nemco_Motorsports_at_Daytona.html |title=Kevin Conway to drive for Nemco Motorsports at Daytona | NASCAR News Now |publisher=SceneDaily.com |accessdate=January 26, 2011}}</ref>
====Entered the series==== For the 2011 season, [[Trevor Bayne]], who placed seventh in the [[2010 NASCAR Nationwide Series]] season, entered the series driving for Wood Brothers Racing in 17 scheduled races.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.inracingnews.com/nascar-news/nascar/bayne-joins-wood-brothers-for-17-races/ |title=Bayne Joins Wood Brothers For 17 Races |publisher=inRacingNews.com |accessdate=January 21, 2011}}</ref> Another driver, [[Brian Keselowski]] also entered the series, after qualifying for the [[2011 Daytona 500]] for the [[K-Automotive Motorsports]] team.<ref name="scenedaily1">{{cite web|author=Post a Comment |url=http://www.scenedaily.com/news/articles/sprintcupseries/Opportunity_is_now_for_underdog_Brian_Keselowski_in_Daytona_500.html |title=Opportunity is now for underdog Brian Keselowski in Daytona 500 | NASCAR News Now |publisher=SceneDaily.com |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref>
====Exited the series==== Some drivers left the series, such as [[Elliott Sadler]] who left Richard Petty Motorsports to drive for [[Kevin Harvick Incorporated]] in the [[Camping World Truck Series]], and [[Nationwide Series]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nascar/story/Elliott-Sadler-to-drive-for-Kevin-Harvick-Inc-in-NASCAR-Nationwide-Series-in-2011-110510 |title=Elliott Sadler to drive for Kevin Harvick Inc. in Nationwide Series in 2011 â NASCAR News | FOX Sports on MSN |publisher=Msn.foxsports.com |date=November 5, 2010 |accessdate=January 18, 2011}}</ref> [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] also exited the series and moved to the [[Nationwide Series]] to participate in ten races, after new sponsorship for his Sprint Cup Series car could not be found.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nascar/story/Sam-Hornish-Jr-lands-NASCAR-ride-for-2011-011511 |title=Roger Penske: Sam Hornish has NASCAR ride for 2011 â NASCAR News | FOX Sports on MSN |publisher=Msn.foxsports.com |accessdate=January 18, 2011}}</ref> After the final race of the 2010 season, [[Scott Speed]] exited the series after Red Bull Racing Team dismissed him to make room for Kahne.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/nascar/story/2010-12-02/scott-speed-released-from-red-bull-racing |title=Scott Speed released from Red Bull Racing â NASCAR |publisher=Sporting News |date=December 2, 2010 |accessdate=February 8, 2011}}</ref> The change resulted in Speed filing a lawsuit against the team for several reasons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scenedaily.com/news/articles/sprintcupseries/Scott_Speed_files_65_million_lawsuit_against_Red_Bull_Racing.html |title=Scott Speed files $6.5 million lawsuit against Red Bull Racing | NASCAR News Now |publisher=SceneDaily.com |accessdate=February 8, 2011}}</ref>
====Mid-season changes==== During July 2011, [[Max Q Motorsports]] announced that [[Scott Speed]] signed a three race contract with the team to race at [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]], [[Watkins Glen International]] and [[Pocono Raceway]]. Following the announcement, Speed commented, "I am excited to get back to the track. Max Q Motorsports seems to have a good operation and a great group of guys. Ford has a great engine package, so I'm hopeful that we can get the ball rolling quickly and be competitive out the gate."<ref name="speedgetsride">{{cite web | url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110726/notebook-sspeed-esadler-tpeck/index.html | title=Notebook: Speed gets ride for Brickyard 400 | publisher=Nascar.com | date=July 26, 2011 | accessdate=July 28, 2011 | author=Sporting News Wire Service}}</ref>
===Rookie entries=== At the beginning of the season, two drivers announced plans to participate in the 2011 Rookie of the Year standings. The drivers were [[Andy Lally]] driving for [[Kevin Buckler|Kevin Buckler's]] [[TRG Motorsports]], and [[Brian Keselowski]], moving his family-operated [[K-Automotive Motorsports]] team up from the Natinowide Series. <ref name="scenedaily1"/> [[Trevor Bayne]], who was running half the season with the [[Wood Brothers]], did not participate in the standings after deciding to participate for the Nationwide Series championship.<ref>{{cite web|author=Reid Spencer |url=http://www.sportingnews.com/nascar/story/2011-02-10/bayne-will-have-to-postpone-cup-rookie-run |title=Bayne will have to postpone Cup rookie run â NASCAR |publisher=Sporting News |date=February 10, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref> [[T.J. Bell]] entered later in the season and collected his first Cup points at Pocono. As Lally was the only rookie driver to run the required 17 races to keep eligibility, he won the rookie award easily despite being released from TRG before Homestead.
==2011 calendar== On August 18, 2010, the final calendar was released containing 36 races, with the addition of two exhibition races. The schedule also includes two [[Gatorade Duel]]s, which are the qualifying races for the [[Daytona 500]].<ref name="2011announced">{{cite news|last=Release|first=Official|title=2011 NASCAR Schedule|url=http://www.nascar.com/2010/news/headlines/official/08/18/2011.nascar.cup.nationwide.truck.schedule/index.html|accessdate=August 23, 2010|newspaper=NASCAR|date=August 18, 2010}}</ref> <!-- Please only add official sponsorships and times that are either on Jayski.com or nascar.com, or on the track pages. ===Calendar changes=== {{main|NASCAR Realignment#Realignment 2011|l1=2011 NASCAR realignment}}
For the 2011 season, NASCAR made several changes to the schedule. One change was that the [[Subway Fresh Fit 500|Subway Fresh Fit 600]], held at [[Phoenix International Raceway]], was reduced to 500 kilometers, making the name Subway Fresh Fit 500, and it became the second race of the season.<ref name="phoenixint.">{{cite web|title=Phoenix receives second race on 2011 schedule|url=http://www.nascar.com/2010/news/headlines/cup/08/10/pir.date.change/index.html|publisher=NASCAR|accessdate=August 10, 2010}}</ref> Also the [[Atlanta 500|Kobalt Tools 500]], held at [[Atlanta Motor Speedway]], was discontinued.<ref name="atlantalose">{{cite web|title=Atlanta to play host to one race weekend in 2011|url=http://www.nascar.com/2010/news/headlines/cup/08/05/ams.one.date/index.html|accessdate=August 7, 2010|location=NASCAR}}</ref> The [[Auto Club 400|Auto Club 500]] at [[Auto Club Speedway]], was reduced to 400 miles making the name Auto Club 400,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scenedaily.com/news/articles/sprintcupseries/Auto_Club_Speedway_race_changed_from_500_miles_to_400_miles.html |title=Auto Club Speedway race changed from 500 miles to 400 miles | NASCAR News Now |publisher=SceneDaily.com |accessdate=January 13, 2011}}</ref> and became the fifth race of the season.<ref name=phoenixint. /> More changes to the schedule included [[Kansas Speedway]] gaining a race (the [[2011 STP 400|STP 400]]), which was ran on June 5, 2011,<ref name="kansas">{{cite news|title=AP: Kansas to get second NASCAR Sprint Cup race|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/nascar/2010-08-06-kansas-second-nascar-date_N.htm|work=USA Today|accessdate=August 10, 2010 | date=August 6, 2010}}</ref> and [[Kentucky Speedway]] hosted its first [[Sprint Cup Series]] race, the [[2011 Quaker State 400|Quaker State 400]] on July 9, 2011.<ref name="kentoget">{{cite web|title=Finally, Kentucky gets its long-awaited Cup date|url=http://www.nascar.com/2010/news/headlines/cup/08/10/kentucky.speedway.cup.race/index.html|accessdate=August 10, 2010|location=NASCAR}}</ref> The Chase schedule was changed to the [[GEICO 400]] becoming the first race in the [[Chase for the Sprint Cup]]; the [[Sylvania 300]] at [[New Hampshire Motor Speedway]] was the second, while [[Auto Club Speedway]]'s [[Pepsi Max 400]] was removed.<ref name="chicagolandchase">{{cite web|title=Chicago gets first Chase race of 2011|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/nascar/cup/news/story?id=5448962|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=August 10, 2010}}</ref>
====Starting times==== Another change for the season involves the races in the [[Chase for the Sprint Cup]], which had different starting times so they would not conflict with the beginning of [[National Football League|NFL]] games. The change was made after seven races during the 2010 season began at 1:00 pm EST, the same time as the NFL games began. The change delayed the start of the first six races, excluding Charlotte, to 2:00 pm [[Eastern Daylight Time|EDT]], while the last three started at 3:00 pm [[Eastern Time Zone|EST]]. Charlotte Motor Speedway's race remained on Saturday night.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sporting News Wire Service |url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110127/chase-start-times-adjusted/index.html |title=Chase race start times adjusted for 2011 season â Jan 27, 2011 |publisher=Nascar.Com |accessdate=January 28, 2011}}</ref>. [[Martinsville Speedway]]'s October race on Halloween weekend features a 1:30 pm [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] start because the track does not carry lights, and as a result is using the 2004-09 start time of 1:30 PM EDT.
==Changes== ===Rule changes=== After the [[2010 NASCAR Sprint Cup Series|2010 season]], the [[Crew chief (auto racing)|catch can man]], who caught excess fuel during pit stops and adjusts the [[Panhard rod|track bar]], is no longer needed, because of the addition of a self-venting fuel can.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scenedaily.com/news/articles/sprintcupseries/NASCAR_to_eliminate_catch_cans_for_2011_in_all_series.html |title=NASCAR to eliminate catch cans for 2011 in all series | NASCAR News Now |newspaper=SceneDaily.com |date=October 9, 2010 |accessdate=December 6, 2010}}</ref> On January 11, 2011, NASCAR reported drivers can only be able to compete for the championship in one of NASCAR's three national racing series, which means the drivers who race in multiple series, most notably in [[Buschwhacker|the Cup and Nationwide Series]], are able to compete in the races, but not for the championship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110110/rule-change-drivers-one-championship/index.html |title=NASCAR drivers must elect championships in '11 |first=Dave |last=Rodman |work=NASCAR.com |date=January 11, 2011 |accessdate=January 11, 2011}}</ref>
The rule does not affect the exemption rule, as exemptions are determined by the top 35 in NASCAR car owner points. Drivers ineligible for Sprint Cup driver points earned Sprint Cup owner points for their team.
An announcement came on January 26, 2011, when [[Brian France]] announced that the winner of the race, excluding bonus points would receive 43 points, and each position lost one point from the position before, so that the first position would receive 43 points, while second would receive 42.<ref>{{cite news|last=Network |first=Sports |url=http://www.kentucky.com/2011/01/26/1612808/nascar-adopts-new-points-system.html#more |title=NASCAR adopts new points system, changes format for Chase | Auto Racing |work=[[Lexington Herald-Leader]] |accessdate=January 27, 2011}}</ref> For bonus points, if the driver leads a lap they receive one, if they lead the most laps they receive one more, and if they win the race they receive three more points.<ref>{{cite news|last=Utter |first=Jim |url=http://www.thatsracin.com/2011/01/26/54366/will-nascars-new-points-add-up.html |title=Will NASCAR's new points add up with fans? |publisher=www.thatsracin.com |accessdate=January 27, 2011}}</ref> On the same day, France announced changes to the qualifying format, such as the qualifying order being set by practice speeds from slowest to highest. If qualifying is canceled, the grid would be determined by practice speeds, unless they are also cancelled, then they lined up by Drivers' points. In the press conference, it was also noted that in the [[Chase for the Sprint Cup]], the eleventh and twelfth positions would be awarded to whoever has the most victories who are ranked from 11th to 20th in regular-season driver's points. Those drivers would not be given bonus points for wins.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110126/nascar-rules-changes/index.html |title=Changes for 2011 include emphasis on winning â Jan 26, 2011 |publisher=NASCAR |date=January 26, 2011 |accessdate=January 27, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.catchfence.com/2011/sprintcup/01/26/nascar-points-system-changes-to-add-more-excitement-to-mis-events/ |title=NASCAR points system changes to add more excitement to MIS events |publisher=Catchfence |date=January 26, 2009 |accessdate=January 27, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/nascar/cup/news/story?id=6062289 |title=NASCAR chairman Brian France announces new points system â ESPN |publisher=ESPN |date=January 1, 2008 |accessdate=January 27, 2011}}</ref> In addition, the number of base points received by Chase drivers at the points reset were set at 2,000 instead of the previous 5,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nascar.com/news/110128/chase-format/index.html |title=10-race Chase for the Cup crowns series champ |work=NASCAR 101 |publisher=NASCAR |date=January 28, 2011 |accessdate=March 6, 2011}}</ref>
===Sponsorship changes=== During the 2010 off-season, [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]] and [[Pennzoil]] became the primary sponsors of Kurt Busch's new team at Penske Racing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/nascar/cup/news/story?id=5121303 |title=Kurt Busch signs extension at Penske, with Shell/Pennzoil as sponsor â ESPN |publisher=ESPN |date=April 21, 2010 |accessdate=December 6, 2010}}</ref> [[Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)|Budweiser]] decided to end their association with [[Richard Petty Motorsports]], and instead replaced Shell and Pennzoil at [[Richard Childress Racing]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Sporting News Wire Service |url=http://www.nascar.com/2010/news/headlines/cup/08/17/kharvick.budweiser.sponsorship/index.html |title=Budweiser moving sponsorship to Harvick in 2011 â Aug 17, 2010 |publisher=Nascar.Com |date=August 17, 2010 |accessdate=December 6, 2010}}</ref> [[Mobil 1]], [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]]'s primary sponsor in 2010, moved their sponsorship to [[Tony Stewart]] at [[Stewart Haas Racing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/nascar/cup/news/story?id=5674391&source=RPMHeadlines |title=Tony Stewart adds Mobil 1 as primary sponsor â ESPN |publisher=ESPN |date=October 12, 2010 |accessdate=December 6, 2010}}</ref> The primary sponsor of the 24 Hendrick Motorsports [[Chevrolet]] driven by Jeff Gordon became [[AARP]]'s "Drive to End Hunger", replacing [[DuPont]], which became his associative sponsor. As part of [[Paul Menard]]'s move to Richard Childress Racing, he took his family-owned business, [[Menards]], with him.<ref>{{cite web|author=Team Release |url=http://www.nascar.com/2010/news/headlines/cup/08/11/pmenard.rcr.fourth.car/index.html |title=RCR signs Menard, returns to four-car stable â Aug 11, 2010 |publisher=Nascar.Com |date=August 11, 2010 |accessdate=December 7, 2010}}</ref>
===Other changes=== During the 2010 season through the off-season, NASCAR announced a change to the [[Coachwork|front end]] of the race cars. The change removed the [[Diffuser (automotive)|splitter braces]], and made it a single molded piece.<ref>{{cite news|author=Post a Comment |url=http://www.scenedaily.com/news/articles/sprintcupseries/Teams_already_working_on_cars_with_new_2011_nose.html |title=Teams already working on cars with new 2011 front splitter | NASCAR News Now |publisher=SceneDaily.com |date=October 12, 2010 |accessdate=January 24, 2011}}</ref> The fuel for all major series in NASCAR changed from [[Sunoco]] [[gasoline|unleaded]] to an [[Ethanol fuel|ethanol]] blend called 'Sunoco Green [[E15 fuel|E15]]'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.speedwaymedia.com/articles/Story.php?S=4461016101833 |title=NASCAR going green; E15 fuel next season |publisher=Speedwaymedia.com |date=October 16, 2010 |accessdate=December 7, 2010}}</ref>
